description.en: What should we do and why? What should we believe and why? The course, running during the first semester, offers an advanced introduction to concepts, topics, and arguments in contemporary ethics and epistemology, both separately as well as highlighting their mutual relations. The course covers material, which is normally not covered at undergraduate level, while also offering an entry point for those who have not studied philosophy before.
description.et: Mida me peaksime tegema ja miks? Mida me peaksime uskuma ja miks? See esimese semestri õppeaine annab süvendatud sissejuhatuse kaasaegse eetika ja epistemoloogia mõistetesse, teemadesse ja argumentidesse, nii eraldivõetuna kui ka nende vastastikuseid seoseid rõhutades. Käsitletakse materjali, mida tavaliselt filosoofia bakalaureusetasemel veel ei käsitleta, pakkudes samas ka alusteadmisi neile magistrantidele, kes pole varem filosoofiat õppinud.

objectives.en: This course provides an intensive introduction to topics in Ethics and Epistemology: both disciplines which study normative questions about how to act and how to think, respectively. The course also trains students in the anatomy, formulation and evaluation of argument - both in written and oral philosophical exchanges.
objectives.et: Kursus pakub intensiivset sissejuhatust eetikasse ja epistemoloogiasse: need on filosoofia harud, mis uurivad normatiivseid küsimusi selle kohta, kuidas tegutseda ja mõelda. Õpitakse ka argumentide anatoomiat, koostamist ja hindamist nii kirjalikes kui ka suulistes filosoofilistes aruteludes.

description.et:
The learning outcomes (LO) are:  
1. having knowledge of contemporary debates in ethics and epistemology as well as of their mutual relation, 
2. being able to identify various parts of a philosophical view (thesis, arguments in favour, objections, location within a specific debate),
3. having practiced skills of argument-making and argument evaluation,
4. having trained philosophical writing and philosophical discussion skills,
5. as a result of the foregoing, being prepared for the other modules of the Master's program .

Assessment is spread throughout the course. Each mini-essay will receive feedback which helps students improve their writing for the next mini-essay and for the final essay. Each assessment method will be designed to check achievement of one or more of the learning outcomes: 

* 2 Mini-essays: Primarily LO1, LO2, LO3, insofar as each mini-essay variously includes both a comprehension task and an argumentative task (recognizing an argument from a text, constructing a new argument, objecting to an argument, improving an argument, in favor of or against a certain philosophical thesis). It checks LO4 to the extent that the professional quality of the writing will be assessed.
One mini-essay will be on the ethics section, one mini-essay will be on the epistemology section.

* Attendance and active participation in lectures and seminars. Participation in seminars will consist in either discussion of a specific course material or in collective discussion of the mini-essays through a system of (mock) peer-review by students. This will check achievement of all LOs. In particular lectures will serve LO1 while seminars will serve the other outcomes in terms of oral and on-the-go argumentation skills.

* Final essay: This will check achievement of all LOs, but in particular LO1, as the essay must demonstrate advanced knowledge of at least some area of debate described in the essay title, and LO4, as the essay consists in a somewhat extended (compared to the mini-essays) elaboration of an argument in favor of or against a certain view. Evidence of lack of progress in terms of all LOs from the mini-essays to the final essay, especially in terms of being unresponsive to lecturer's feedback, will be duly noted and regarded as a possible reason for failing the course.
Students will be able to choose the title of their final essay from a given list or in agreement with the lecturers.

- Final essay (30% of final grade)

description.et:
Each topic will normally be taught for one week in a lecture followed by a seminar on a subsequent day.

Week 1
Introduction: Why ethics? Why epistemology? Why together?

Week 2 
A quick overview of "normative ethics": consequentialism and its rivals
Text TBA

Week 3 
Challenges to ethics: 1) Ethics is false 
Mackie, John (1977). Ethics: Inventing Right and Wrong, chapter 1.

Week 4 
Challenges to ethics: 2) Ethics evolves 
Street, Sharon (2006). A Darwinian dilemma for realist theories of value. Philosophical Studies 127 (1):109-166.

Week 5 
You've got your reasons (for action), I've got mine?
Williams, Bernard (1981). Internal and external reasons. In Moral Luck, Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1981, 101–113.

Week 6 
Is ethical disagreement a problem?
Enoch, David (2011), Taking Morality Seriously, chapter 8

Week 7
Seminar only: Preparation for the first mini-essay, 

Week 8
Submission of first mini-essay.

Week 9 
Reasons for belief / epistemic rationality. Are there distinctly epistemic reasons?

Week 10
Knowledge is the central epistemic normative concept. Or is it?

Week 11
Justification I: Internalism

Week 12
Justification II: Externalism

Week 13 
Epistemic value: understanding and knowledge

Week 14 
Joining loose threads and course recap - Seminar: Preparation for the second mini-essay.

Week 15
Submission of second mini-essay.

TBA
Submission of final essay.
